Title: Prefrontal Projections to the Mediodorsal Nucleus of the Thalamus in the Rhesus monkey
Abstract:
"The corticothalamic projections to the prefrontal cortex have  been shown to be topographically organized. However, the
underlying basis for this topography as it relates to the organization of the different architectonically defined areas of the
prefrontal cortex has not been systematically studied. In the present investigation we have reassessed the thalamic
projections from the different architectonic areas of the prefrontal cortex by using the technique of autoradiography in the rhesus monkey. The results show that the prefronto-mediodorsal projections are organized according to the architectonic
differentiation of the prefrontal cortices. Thus architectonically less differentiated medial and orbital prefrontal regions project to the medial sector of the mediodorsal nucleus, the magnocellular subdivision. In contrast, highly differentiated prefrontal area 8 projects to the most lateral sector of the mediodorsal nucleus, the multiformis subdivision. Lateral prefrontal areas with intermediate architectonic features project to the central parvocellular sector of the mediodorsal nucleus. Additionally, these projections also reveal a dorsoventral topography. Thus areas in the medial and dorsolateral cortices project to the dorsal part of the mediodorsal nucleus. In contrast, areas in orbital and ventrolateral cortices project to the ventral part of the mediodorsal nucleus. The topographic organization of the corticothalamic connections described in this study corresponds to the progressive elaboration and differentiation of the architectonic features of the different prefrontal areas. This successive and dichotomous organization of prefrontothalamic connections may provide the basis for the observed differential functions of the prefrontal cortex and the mediodorsal nucleus."

In describing the results we adopted Walker's nomenclature (40a)... Area 25 is relegated to the cortex lying below the rostrum of the corpus callosum."

@Injections.Citation: "In case 1 (Fig. 3A), the injection mainly involved Pro and area 13 with some slight encroachment on adjoining area 12."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In all four cases [case 1 to 4], label was observed in the medial portion of MD, MDmc,... In cases 1 and 3 ... label extended more ventrally within MDmc (Fig. 3A, panel 3C panels 1-4)... In each of the above cases, the label occurred in patches, containing areas devoid of silver grains (see Fig. 7A)."

@Injections.Citation: "... in case 10 (Fig. 5A), the injection was confined primarily to area 32 with some involvement of adjacent area 24."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Transported tracer [in cases 9 and 10] was observed in the dorsomedial portion of MDpc along the length of the nucleus."

@Injections.Citation: "In case 11 (Fig. 5B), the injection was placed ventromedially in the prefrontal cortex an involved areas 25 and 14."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "The label in this case [case 11] was seen mainly in the dorsal aspect of MDmc (see Fig. 7D) with some tracer extending into dorsomedial MDpc... In all cases, the labeling had a patchy distribution having distinct label free zones."

@Injections.Citation: "In case 12 (Fig. 5C), the injection involved the dorsal bank of the principal sulcus (areas 9 and 46)."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In cases 12 and 13, label was located predominantly within the central region of dorsal MDpc."

@Injections.Citation: "Case 13 (not illustrated) received an injcection in the region dorsal the principle sulcus (area 9)."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In cases 13, in which the injection involved areas 46 and 9, the label in MDpc was more dorsally displaced than in case 12."

@Injections.Citation: "In case 14 (Fig. 6A), isotope was injected into the dorsal portion of area 46 and extended into the dorsal portion of area 8."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation:
"In case 14, label was observed in the dorsal and lateral portion of MDpc. In addition, label was seen in the rostral portion of MDmf. The involvement of MDmf in this case could be attributed to the injection having involved area 8."
"The labeling in MDpc in case 15 can be attributed to the injection having involved area 46 since a similar pattern of labeling was observed in case 14... In these cases, the label was distributed as a dense patch of tracer that adhered closely to the lateral border of MDmf."

@Injections.Citation: "The injection in case 15 (Fig. 6B) involved the rostral portion of dorsal area 8 with some involvement of dorsal area 46."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In both cases [cases 15 and 16], label was seen in the dorsal portionof MDmf. In case 15, however, additional label was noted in the lateral MDpc. The labeling in MDpc in case 15 can be attributed to the injection having involved area 46 since a similar pattern of labeling was observed in case 14... In these cases, the label was distributed as a dense patch of tracer that adhered closely to the lateral border of MDmf."

@Injections.Citation: "The injection in case 16 (Fig. 6C) was restricted to area 8 in the anterior bank of the dorsal arcuate sulcus."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In both cases [cases 15 and 16], label was seen in the dorsal portion of MDmf."

@Injections.Citation: "In case 2 (Fig. 3B), the injection was principally in area 14, but also extended into adjacent areas 11 and 13."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In all four cases [case 1 to 4], label was observed in the medial portion of MD, MDmc,... publication.title: Prefrontal Projections to the Mediodorsal Nucleus of the Thalamus in the Rhesus monkey
publication.abstract:
"The corticothalamic projections to the prefrontal cortex have  been shown to be topographically organized. However, the
underlying basis for this topography as it relates to the organization of the different architectonically defined areas of the

In contrast, areas in orbital and ventrolateral cortices project to the ventral part of the mediodorsal nucleus. The topographic organization of the corticothalamic connections described in this study corresponds to the progressive elaboration and differentiation of the architectonic features of the different prefrontal areas. This successive and dichotomous organization of prefrontothalamic connections may provide the basis for the observed differential functions of the prefrontal cortex and the mediodorsal nucleus."
